children.name: the poor c1
children.definition: poor people/the poor/the needy/ˈpʊəʳ ˌpiːpəl, ðə ˈpʊəʳ, ðə ˈniːdi/  the people in a society who are poor:
examples: ▪ the poor always suffer worst in a recession.
▪ it was fairly common in victorian times for middle-class women to work among the needy in the big industrial cities.
▪ finding adequate housing for the poor has been one of the city council’s priorities.
▪ the technological revolution has failed to improve the lives of poor people in developing countries.
the poor ngườinghèo túng; nghèo khổ
poor people considered together as a group
_housing for the poor

children.name: the needy x
children.definition: poor people/the poor/the needy/ˈpʊəʳ ˌpiːpəl, ðə ˈpʊəʳ, ðə ˈniːdi/  the people in a society who are poor:
examples: ▪ the poor always suffer worst in a recession.
▪ it was fairly common in victorian times for middle-class women to work among the needy in the big industrial cities.
▪ finding adequate housing for the poor has been one of the city council’s priorities.
▪ the technological revolution has failed to improve the lives of poor people in developing countries.
the needy ngườinghèo túng; nghèo khổ
poor people
_let us pray for those who are not so fortunate as ourselves - the sick, the old and the needy.

children.name: the have-nots x
children.definition: the have-nots/ðə ˈhæv nɒts/  the people in society who are poor and have very few possessions compared to people who have a high income and own property, cars etc:
examples: the haves and have-nots : người giàu kẻ nghèo
▪ society seems to be increasingly divided into the haves rich people and have-nots.
the haves and have-nots người giàu kẻ nghèo
the people who are not poor and the people who are poor
_the government's change of policy is intended to reduce
the gap between the haves and have-nots in our society.

children.name: the underprivileged x
children.definition: the underprivileged những người bị thiệt thòi
examples: polite phrase for poor people
_the charity raises money for holidays for the underprivileged.

children.name: the disadvantaged x
children.definition: the disadvantaged nhữngngười chịu thiệt thòi
examples: people who do not have good living conditions, a good
standard of education, etc., considered as a group
_these measures are intended to help the disadvantaged.

children.name: poor people a1
children.definition: poor people/the poor/the needy/ˈpʊəʳ ˌpiːpəl, ðə ˈpʊəʳ, ðə ˈniːdi/  the people in a society who are poor:
examples: ▪ the poor always suffer worst in a recession.
▪ it was fairly common in victorian times for middle-class women to work among the needy in the big industrial cities.
▪ finding adequate housing for the poor has been one of the city council’s priorities.
▪ the technological revolution has failed to improve the lives of poor people in developing countries.

children.name: poor a1
children.definition: poor/pʊəʳ/
examples: ▪ they were so poor they couldn’t afford to buy shoes for their children.
▪ she was born in a poor district of chicago in 1925.
▪ people who live in poor countries have a much lower life expectancy.
▪ these cuts will hit the poorest members of society.
▪ some democrats believed they lost the election because many poor women didn’t turn out to vote.
dirt pooramerican extremely poor
▪ her mother grew up dirt poor among migrant workers in alabama.
pooradjectiveno moneynghèo, túng, bần cùng
having little money and/or few possessions
_most of the world's poorest countries are inafrica.
_he came from a poor immigrant family.

children.name: badly off x
children.definition: badly off/ˌbædli ˈɒf/having less money than most other people:
examples: thiếu thốn
▪ she was quite badly off for a while after her husband died.
▪ we were pretty poor, but most of our friends were even worse off.
▪ no matter how badly off we were, we never went to bed hungry.

children.name: needy/in need x
children.definition: needy/in need/ˈniːdi, ɪn ˈniːd/  needy people or people who are in need do not have enough money to buy food, clothes etc, and deserve help:
examples: nghèo túng thiếu thốn
▪ the fund was established to help needy widows whose husbands had died in the war.
▪ more aid should be given to needy families.
▪ all profits from the concert will go to help children in need.
in need
not having enough money or food
_you just hope that the money goes to those who are most in need.

children.name: impoverished x
children.definition: impoverished/ɪmˈpɒvərɪʃtǁ-ˈpɑː-/ formalvery poor - use this especially aboutpeopleorplacesthat werenot poor in the past:
examples: bần cùng hóa
▪ his family became so impoverished they were forced to sell the farm.
▪ all there was in the region was dry soil and impoverished villages.

children.name: poverty-stricken x
children.definition: poverty-stricken/ˈpɒvəʳti ˌstrɪkənǁˈpɑː-/writtenextremelypoor, and suffering as a result of this:
examples: nghèo xơ xác
▪ at the moment, many poverty-stricken communities are experiencing a shortage of teachers.
▪ his photographs show vividly the lives of poverty-stricken families in the gorbals area of glasgow.

children.name: destitute x
children.definition: destitute/ˈdestɪtjuːt, ˈdestətjuːtǁ-tuːt/  especiallywrittenhaving no money or possessions, and often nowhere to live, especially when there seems to be no possibility of improving the situation:
examples: nghèo túng cơ cực
▪ in 1860 father murphy set up a home for orphans and destitute children.
▪ the rest of her family all died in a smallpox epidemic, leaving her destitute.

children.name: an area where poor people live
inner city x
children.definition: inner city/ˌɪnəʳ ˈsɪti◂/  the part near the middle of a city where the buildings are in bad condition and where a lot of poor people live:
examples: khu ổ chuột
▪ the problems of britain’s inner cities
inner-city[adjective only before noun]
▪ inner-city schools

children.name: slum x
children.definition: slum/slʌm/  an area of a city where the houses are in very bad condition and the people are very poor and live in dirty, crowded, and unhealthy conditions:
examples: khu ổ chuột
▪ maria lives with her eight children in a slum outside montevideo.
the slums
▪ i grew up in the east london slums.

children.name: ghetto x
children.definition: ghetto/ˈgetəʊ/  a poor and crowded part of a city, where people liveseparatelyfrom the rest of the population, especially people ofoneraceor fromonecountry.inner city is now morecommonthan ghetto:
examples: khu ổ chuột
▪ a novel about life in the ghettos of new york
▪ ottovina lived on the south side, in the italian ghetto, and barely spoke any english at all.

children.name: when people have very little money
poverty b2
children.definition: poverty/ˈpɒvəʳtiǁˈpɑː-/
examples: ▪ charles was shocked by the poverty he saw in india.
▪ poverty and unemployment are two of the biggest causes of crime
dire/abject/grinding etc povertyextreme poverty
▪ seven out of every 10 guatemalans live in dire poverty and half cannot read or write.
live/grow up/be raised etc in poverty
▪ old people should not have to live in poverty.
the poverty line/levelthe income below which a person or family is officially considered to be very poor and in need of help: mức nghèo khổ
▪ in louisiana, one person in four lives below the poverty level.
povertynoun[ u ]cảnh nghèo nàn, cảnh bần cùng
the condition of being extremely poor
_two million people in the city live inabject(= very great) poverty.
_he emigrated toaustraliato escape thegrinding(= very great) poverty of his birthplace.
_helping to alleviate poverty in developing countries also helps to reduce environmental destruction.

children.name: hard times u
children.definition: hard times/hɑːʳd ˈtaɪmz/  a period when life is difficult because you have little money -use this when you are comparing this to other, better, times:
examples: thời điểm khó khăn
▪ there were hard times during my childhood when my parents didn’t have work, but generally we were happy.
fall on hard timesbegin to experience hard times
▪ many of the girls were from middle class families who had fallen on hard times.
▪ after the war my father fell on hard times and sank deeply into debt.

children.name: having very little money at the present time
broke x
children.definition: broke/brəʊk/ informalhaving no money at the moment:
examples: túng quẫn, bần cùng
▪ we’re always broke at the end of the month.
▪ lawrence was so broke he had to wear the same suit to work every day.
flat brokecompletely broke
▪ he turned up at my house yesterday, flat broke and hungry.

children.name: hard up x
children.definition: hard up/ˌhɑːʳd ˈʌp◂/ informalhaving little money at the present time and being unable to buy the things that you need:
examples: cháy túi, không một xu dính túi
▪ i’m a little hard up just now -- can i pay you back next week?
▪ she was so hard up that she couldn’t afford to heat her apartment.

children.name: skint x
children.definition: skint/skɪnt/britishspokenhaving no money at all:
examples: tũng quẫn
▪ i’m really skint -- you couldn’t lend me a few quid could you?
▪ at that time i was skint, and i would have taken any job i could get.

children.name: be down on your luck x
children.definition: be down on your luck/biː ˌdaʊn ɒn jɔːʳ ˈlʌk/informalto have had bad luck over a long period of time so that you now have very little money:
examples: gặp vận rủi
▪ we bought the necklace from an old man who was down on his luck and in need of a penny or two.
down-on-your-luck[adjective only before noun]
▪ in the film, williams plays a down-on-his luck salesman whose wife has left him.

children.name: having fewer opportunities in life because of being poor
disadvantaged c1
children.definition: disadvantaged/ˌdɪsədˈvɑːntɪdʒd◂ǁ-ˈvæn-/ especially written disadvantaged people or groups have less chance of being successful in life because they are poor -- used especially in social or political contexts:
examples: thiệt thòi
▪ the university has announced plans to increase the number of students from minority and disadvantaged groups.
▪ quinn argued that an increase in the minimum wage would help the most disadvantaged americans.
disadvantagedadjectivethiệt thòi; thua thiệt
not having the standard of living conditions, education, etc. that most people have
_a new educational programme has been set up for economically disadvantaged children.

children.name: underprivileged x
children.definition: underprivileged/ˌʌndəʳˈprɪvɪlɪdʒd◂, ˌʌndəʳˈprɪvəlɪdʒd◂/having less money and worse living conditions than other people in a society, and little chance of being successful in life:
examples: thiệt thòi
▪ princess anne has done much to help underprivileged children all over the world.

children.name: deprived c1
children.definition: deprived/dɪˈpraɪvd/  deprived peopleare very poor and are not able to find good jobs or get a good education. a deprivedareais one in which people are poor and do not have many advantages:
examples: túng quẫn, thiếu thốn
▪ most mass demonstrations of this type happen in places where people are enormously deprived.
▪ children growing up in deprived areas are far more likely to turn to crime and drug abuse.
▪ girls from deprived backgrounds often become pregnant at an early age.
deprivedadjective túng quẫn; thiếu thốn
not having the things that are necessary for a pleasant life,such as enough money, food or good living conditions
_she had a deprived childhood/comes from a deprived background.
_a deprived area

children.name: developing country/nation b2
children.definition: developing country/nation/dɪˌveləpɪŋ ˈkʌntri, ˈneɪʃən/  a country that is not rich and does not have much industry or business activity:
examples: nước đang phát triển
▪ bellamy called on the united states to increase aid to developing nations.
▪ leaders of developing countries from around the world met in indonesia to devise ways to improve their economies.
developingadjective
describes a country or area of the world which is poorer and has less advanced industries, especially in africa, latin america orasia
_the developing world/countries/nations

children.name: third world x
children.definition: third world/ˌθɜːʳd ˈwɜːʳld◂/  a third world country or nation is poor and does not have much industry. third world is used especially in a negative sense when talking about the problems that these countries face:
examples: thế giới thứ 3 ( những nước đang phát triển )
the third worldthese countries in general
▪ most of the population in the third world is concentrated in large cities.
third world country/nation
▪ sometimes i think that england is becoming a third world country.

children.name: tight b2
children.definition: tightadjectivenot much khan hiếm
examples: if time or money is tight, there is only just enough of it
_i'm sorry i can't stop, time's really tight.
_they're raising three kids on one small salary so money is very tight.

children.name: deprivation c2
children.definition: deprivationnoun
examples: when you do not have things or conditions that are usually considered necessary for a pleasant life
_they used sleep deprivation as a form of torture.
_there is awful deprivation in the shanty towns.
_there were food shortages and other deprivations during the civil war.

children.name: down-and-out c2
children.definition: down-and-outadjectiveđường cùng; nghèo túng; túng quẫn
examples: having no luck, no money and no opportunities
_a down-and-out loser
_nobody loves you when you're down and out.
